captions.text:
People often say to me &quot;Yahtzee, why is it
that you avoid multiplayer games, and when

will you let me off this red hot grating?&quot;
Well, you know, it&#39;s just that I prefer playing

games to relax and unwind at my own pace and
not be disappointed once again by other people

and their unwillingness to learn how to tap
dance properly. But as I said in my Outriders

review stroke widdling session, I can appreciate
a multiplayer game that actually designs itself

around an essential multiplayer experience
and isn&#39;t just chucking three extra players

into The Adventures Of Captain Scowlybuff
and his Many Identical Friends for the sake

of maximising user engagement the way one
maximises the food order of an unpopular restaurant

critic with the addition of bogeys and spit.
So when my editor asked me to check out It

Takes Two, a two and strictly only two player
game, I was like &quot;I&#39;m down for that, as long

as it&#39;s not like that last strictly two player
game I played, the laughably awful A Way Out,

by Hazelight Studios, which played like if
David Cage tried to adapt the Shawshank Redemption,

realised it wasn&#39;t long enough and filled
in the rest of the time with three random

DVDs he found in a bargain bin. Who&#39;s this
new game by, anyway? Oh. Hazelight Studios.

Well, that might have been embarrassing for
someone capable of shame.

Same director as Brothers: A Tale Of Two Sons,
of course. What is it with this fucker and

dual protagonist gameplay, does he just have
really wonky vision? I&#39;m teasing, put away

those widdle umbrellas, audience, because
to my not inconsiderable surprise, It Takes

Two is actually pretty fun. A Way Out was
shooting for gritty crime drama and fell flat

because its rampant cliches, terrible writing
and secondary protagonist with a nose so big

he can&#39;t swim the back stroke without setting
off shark alerts, made it impossible to take

seriously, and so It Takes Two embraces a
lighter tone and a more abstract setting so

that we&#39;re more laughing with it than at it,
and it&#39;s full of enough over the top gameplay

and visuals to keep me distracted from the
frankly still terrible writing. The premise

is, a married couple whose relationship is
bottoming out so hard it&#39;s getting carpet

burns inform their friendless, presumably
homeschooled and probably on the spectrum

daughter that they&#39;re getting divorced. Said
daughter proceeds to cry on some dolls she

made of her parents for Christ knows what
reason and the parents&#39; souls get magically
transferred into the dolls.

Blimey, lucky she didn&#39;t cry into some bog
roll or the sandwich she was eating, that&#39;d&#39;ve

been a bit Kafkaesque. The parents must then
work together to find a way back to normal

by navigating abstract puzzle platforming
fantasy worlds based on aspects of their family

home, which appears to have been about the
size of Windsor fucking Castle. Harangued

from start to finish by an omnipotent self-help
book with a slightly racist accent whom you

and the protagonists will swiftly want to
murder. In fact, I&#39;d&#39;ve given the game&#39;s story

more points if it&#39;d ended with the family
finally coming together over a cheerful backyard

book burning. What should be as obvious up
front as a drastically botched tit job is

that this story arc is going to centre around
a divorcing couple reconciling for the sake

of the kid and I don&#39;t know if that&#39;s a healthy
message to bring across to troubled families,

that divorce only happens &#39;cos you didn&#39;t
try hard enough. Honestly I kept wondering

what the fuck these two ever saw in each other
&#39;cos the mum&#39;s bitchy and uptight and weirdly

reminiscent of Sue Pollard, and the dad&#39;s
whiny and ambitionless and apparently did

nothing with his time other than construct
increasingly elaborate playrooms for his emotionally
stunted offspring.

So the dialogue is a bit cringe... worthy
- Cringeworthy. Worth cringing about. That

is the word. Who&#39;s this fuck who&#39;s been going
around telling you you can use cringe by itself

as an adjective - because the characters are
grating and we have the Sonic Boom problem

where the game is constantly complimenting
itself: &quot;THIS IS AMAZING. THIS IS FANTASTIC.

WOW THE ARTIST OF THIS SHOULD DEFINITELY BE
EARNING A LIVING WAGE&quot;. But none of this is

a deal breaker because (1) you&#39;re playing
with a friend so when it starts getting sappy

you can lean back and take the piss out of
it like the emotional ghoul that you are (2)

it has occasional darkly hilarious moments,
like the extended sequence where the protagonists

set out to drink their daughter&#39;s tears (in
the literal rather than edgy coffee mug sense)

and end up trying to murder her favourite
toy in the most ineptly drawn out way imaginable.

And (3) the game design is actually really
good. At its core it&#39;s an exaggerated Marioesque

3D platformer with a decent enough feel, but
it also layers on puzzles where the two protagonists

are given different, complementary abilities
and have to work together to proceed, and
they&#39;re generally very well designed.

Making the most of the strict two player setup
while relying very minimally on &quot;door is very

heavy, needs two people to lift,&quot; the multiplayer
gameplay equivalent of white noise. Also,

the mechanics are constantly changing. First
she&#39;s got a hammer and he&#39;s got a nail, then

he&#39;s got a spooge gun and she&#39;s got a gun
that detonates spooge and I guess we&#39;re a

fucking third person shooter now, it&#39;s almost
impossible to be bored as the gameplay never

becomes unintuitive enough to break up the
constant flow from scenario to scenario. The

quality isn&#39;t quite consistent, there&#39;s the
odd boring rail shooter bit or we get dropped

into an open area full of pointless toys and
minigames where we&#39;re tacitly invited to fuck

around for a while, but that would force me
to spend more time in the presence of the

main characters and frankly if I&#39;d met them
at a dinner party I&#39;d be fobbing them off

to make small talk with the fucking aquarium.
But these moments never last and three minutes

later you&#39;re standing on an aeroplane&#39;s wing
kung fu fighting a squirrel and your engagement

jumps back up again. It does mean that the
plot feels like it&#39;s pinging around all over

the place and is more a pile of unrelated
ideas strung randomly together than a cohesive
journey with a beginning, middle and end,

But at least it&#39;s always pulling out something
new and interesting. Which is all the more

impressive &#39;cos it&#39;s such a long game at around
10-12 hours. Obnoxiously long, I&#39;d say, but

then I&#39;m a professional reviewer with deadlines
to meet who can&#39;t even last two hours around

another person without completely alienating
myself. Which tangentially brings me to one

awkward overhanging question that I have - who
the fuck is this game for? It&#39;s designed for

couch co-op and there&#39;s outwardly a family
friendly vibe but I couldn&#39;t picture myself

playing through it with a child of my own.
Tonally it&#39;s all over the place, and it might

lead to some awkward questions if your own
family has seen some drama. &quot;No, of course

mummy and daddy didn&#39;t split up because of
you, we just never quite figured out how to

get past the boss fight with the vacuum cleaner.&quot;
The bottom line is, it&#39;s a game throwing an

awful lot of shit at the wall, a lot of which
doesn&#39;t stick but enough of it does, and moment

to moment gameplay&#39;s as tight as a gnat&#39;s
arse. I just wrote a compliment that included

the words arse, shit, and bottom. And that&#39;s
why I&#39;m a professional, kids.
